Have you ever noticed you don‚Äôt quite look the same in photos as you do in the mirror?

The reason isn‚Äôt just lighting‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs AI. Your phone camera isn't capturing reality; it's quietly reshaping it.

Look closely. Every time you snap a picture, powerful AI algorithms instantly analyze what‚Äôs in
the frame. They detect faces, objects, and environments, then automatically tweak things to look ‚Äúbetter‚Äù. 

#tech #technology #stem #ai

What happens when a robot doesn‚Äôt know what to do?

No script. No instructions. Just a task ‚Äî and it has to figure it out.

But here‚Äôs the catch: In the real world, failure isn‚Äôt free. A bad decision can break something ‚Äî
or someone could get hurt.
So how do we make robots that learn safely?

Reinforcement learning lets a robot explore. Try something. Get a reward if it works, a penalty if
it doesn‚Äôt. Over time, it builds a policy ‚Äî its internal guide for what to do next.

But not all robots learn this way.
Some copy humans ‚Äî that‚Äôs imitation learning. Others follow strict rules. The best systems blend all three.

A delivery robot, for example, might use physics to stay upright, imitation to handle crowds, and
reinforcement learning to react to surprises.

To make that safe, we start with sim-to-real transfer ‚Äî the robot trains in simulation first.

Then we use human-in-the-loop learning ‚Äî people guide and reinforce good behavior.

And we add safety constraints ‚Äî hard-coded limits on force, speed, and movement.

So yeah ‚Äî robots are learning. Just like we do. A little messy. A lot of math. And one mistake at
a time. And that‚Äôs what makes it exciting.

#tech #robotics #stem #ai

Is it worth learning to code in 2025? Here is how I would go about it differently if I was to start all over again. 

#tech #technology #stem #coding

Let‚Äôs build a machine learning model to make predictions about F1s upcoming Japan GP. 

The model has three key components:
	1.	A Linear Regression model trained on historical qualifying lap data ‚Äî it finds a line through the data that helps us predict future values
	2.	A performance factor system to capture unique team and driver strengths
	3.	A robust data preprocessing pipeline to handle missing data effectively 

Our model uses Q1 and Q2 lap times as input features to predict Q3 times. It learns correlations such as Q1 to Q3, Q2 to Q3, team performance trends, and driver consistency.

We then can enhance these ML predictions by integrating domain-specific multipliers:
	‚Ä¢	Team factors (text in screen: e.g., Red Bull at 0.997, offering a 0.3-second advantage)
	‚Ä¢	Driver factors (text on screen: e.g., Max Verstappen at 0.998, providing a 0.2-second advantage)
	‚Ä¢	Considerations for track evolution over the session

Every time you swipe on your phone, you're falling for a psychological trick invented before the internet even existed. 

Tech companies didn't design touchscreens around our needs - they exploited research that mapped exactly how our brains and fingers work.

Heres how it works.. Back in 1954, long before computers were in every home, psychologist

Paul Fitts made a discovery that would change everything about how we interact with technology today. He figured out exactly how our fingers work‚Äîspecifically, the precise relationship between movement speed and accuracy when tapping targets of different sizes.

This became Fitts' Law‚Äîand here‚Äôs the wild part: The reason buttons on your iPhone are around 9-10mm wide isn‚Äôt some Apple innovation. It‚Äôs because those 1950s experiments proved that‚Äôs the ideal size for human fingertips.

#tech #technology #stem #futuretech #techinnovation

This is MINDBLOWING ü§Ø 

Scientists are working on the fourth dimension for 4D printing, which is time. These materials can actually transform themselves AFTER being printed‚Äîchanging shape, properties, or function in response to triggers like temperature or moisture.

So here's a weird thing ‚Äì we all use the internet every day, but have you ever wondered who actually runs it? Its actually more complicated than you probably realize.

#tech #technology #internet #ai

Here's something wild‚Äîevery time you do anything online, your data travels the internet in tiny fragments called packets. But did you know that someone might be looking inside those packets? It‚Äôs called Deep Packet Inspection, or DPI, and it‚Äôs like X-ray vision for your internet traffic.

So how does it work? Normally, internet routers just look at packet headers‚Äîessentially the digital envelope that says where data is going. But with DPI, network operators peek inside the envelope, examining the actual contents.

ISPs use it to manage network traffic, cybersecurity systems use it to detect malware, and some governments use it for surveillance or censorship.

#tech #technology #coding #stem #futuretech

What if I told you the internet has a trust problem? Right now, when you check your bank account, your data travels through networks that mostly‚Ä¶ trust each other. Limited verification, and often, no security checks at all.

The Border Gateway Protocol, is like the internet‚Äôs GPS. But unlike your phone‚Äôs GPS, this 1980s system lacks built-in security. When a network says, ‚ÄúSend your Amazon traffic through me!‚Äù‚Äîother networks often just believe it.

In 2022 alone, researchers spotted over 10,000 suspicious routing incidents. A famouns incident is when hackers hijacked Amazon‚Äôs Route 53 service, redirected users to a fake site, and stole $150,000 in cryptocurrency.

So why isn‚Äôt this fixed?
